"All right," Raven sighed, as though she were bored of betting. "But I want five coins up front, and not the tin ones, either." Everyone agreed that was fair. She took a deep breath, then drew her long dagger. 'Father will not like this,' she thought with a slight giggle. While most days she minded her father, there were some days when she could care less about embarrassing him.

Raven took another breath, and stepped out into the clearing. The squires had not noticed her yet, and she was glad. She decided to take on the larger man first; maybe the slighter one would help. They had not deigned to notice her, although she was certain they had. She WAS half way across the field at this point. "Sirrahs, of what do you fight?" "This man," said the large guy, "insulted my lord."

"Only after he insulted MY lord, boy, Why do you ask?" Raven was taken aback. No one had ever thought her a BOY before. "Well, I would like to challenge one of you. And since you, Sirrah, seem to be most at fault," she aimed her dagger at 'Large,' "then I will help him." The blade was now pointing at 'Skinny.' Both men laughed. "You, boy, think you can beat US? We are squires to the King's bravest knights, and soon we shall be knighted, as well."

"First," Raven said, "you had better stop calling me 'boy.' And second, I will fight you!" They laughed even harder. "Not call you boy? Why? Are you a girl?" She was not going to take any more of this. She stepped up to the large man. "If you think you can win so easy, why don't you draw," she demanded. Deftly, he pulled his own dagger from his side. He thought, 'There is no use to me using my sword, I will win in a moment's time."

They began to parry. Raven was showing her excellent skill with the blade for she was used to fights without proper etiquette, especially from Roger. At last, Raven pushed him back far enough so that he tripped upon a tree root. She grabbed his knife, and held her own dagger to his throat. "If you can win so easily, why did I beat you," she asked, about ready to slay him.

"And why are you about to kill my squire?" said a voice behind her. Whomever the voice belonged to, he lifted her off of the offender. "Well...your squire said that this other guy had insulted you, and he said only after your squire had insulted his Lord, and..." she trailed off, unsure of what to say next.

"And would you belong to that group of boys over there, son," the strange knight was looking in the direction of her friends. She nodded. "What is your name?" he asked, finally. "My name?" she squeaked. "Rob, Sir," she lied. "One of them said you were a girl named Raven." She flushed slightly. "Oh. Was it Roger? He's just jealous of me cause I can beat him in everything." She hoped that the knight would believe her. "How old are you and your group?" he asked.

This time she told the truth. "I'm second oldest at sixteen, and Roger is oldest at seventeen. He'll be eighteen next season, I think. The youngest is ten." "Ah. Well at least that bit of information is the same as what the others told me."

"Kiria! Come back!" I shouted sternly at my hawk. The bird hovered and then made a diving swoop and landed neatly on my gloved hand. I held the strings of his feet tightly and stroked the bird's head. "Well done Kiria, well done, what have you got for me?"
The bird tried to raise it's leg but it couldn't, it was tied to a piece of leather held firmly in my fist. I understood what he wanted me to do immediately and took a small piece of paper from around his leg. I unravelled the paper and read:

"Kane, we need a knight, and quickly. Get any of your stable boys reaady, anyone from the village, we need one as soon as possible. Make him fast, light and agile, there is no need for him to be an excellent fighter. I hope your bird flies faster than a pigeon!"

I looked up at Kiria. "Kiria, my bird, fly again, and find me a child to be a knight. When you have found him come back to me and lead me to him. We must find him before the day is over."

Watching the bird fly away again was heartwrenching, I never knew if he would come back or not, because he was a wild beast, not a homing pigeon. I prayed that he would return to me, and demonstrate his intelligence once more by finding me the perfect boy for the job...

125.content:
The Royal Banquet Hall is reserved only for the most special of occasions, so breakfast is held in the drawing room of the castle. Queen Morganna is, like all other rooms in the castle save for her husband's study, the absolute master of her domain. Under her care, the drawing room is the most enjoyable in the castle. A plain, wooden table is in the center for usual meals, but the Queen utilized most of her budget in providing for a high window. The spacious window (heavily fortified with bars in case of an archery attack) lets in copious amounts of light, and certainly brightens the usually cheery castle. Royal blue tapestries line the walls, creating a cheery feel to the room.

Seated at the table is Morganna herself, a remarkable woman. She is a master of the domestic domain, and quite a diplomatic woman. With almond shaped brown eyes and a plump, ruddy complexion, she is quite unassuming for a monarch, and keeps her light brown hair in a traditional, unassuming style. Seated next to her is Prince Kiltrain, a serious youth of about eighteen. He is a direct contrast to his mother, with a lean, pale complexion, high aristocratic Roman nose, and piercing gray eyes. His blond hair is relatively long, and it hangs to the point of his shoulders. He is quiet, and therefore often misunderstood as pompous, a label his mother highly regrets.
Next to him is Princess Zara, a dour twenty three year old maiden who appears as if she'll never marry. While she looks nearly identical to her mother, she possesses none of Morganna's grace, unassuming nature, or talent. She is a selfish, spoiled, ungrateful little troll in your opoinion, and you'd do well to stay away from her.
Finally, the king. King Asturon is a nobleman, thin and lean, with a hungry look in his grey eyes. He is decisive, but fair, compassionate but orderly, and keeps his subjects happy. You two had the extreme fortune of growing up together, and the King knows that you are far more talented than you let on. His dark green robe and matching shoes suggests that the king is anticipating a hunt later today.
The servants are soon to arrive with the food. Where are you going to sit?

1251222112.content:
Kane goes into the room where Mandy is working. "Can I ask you a few questions, about Raven?"

"Sure, go ahead."
So Kane asks and Mandy answers as best as she can. When he doesn't think she can help he says that he'll leave her to her work and leaves.
He goes out of the castle and toward the village. Then he follows Mandy's discription of where Raven lives. Eventually he finds the farm and knocks on the farmhouse door.
A man answers.

"Hello, sir. What can I do for you?"

"Hello, my name is Kane. Are you Ravens father?"

"Yes I am." The man sighs, "what has she done now?"

"Sorry sir I think you misunderstand. I work at the castle and I was wondering if you would have any objections to her coming to work in the kitchens there? That is of course if she wants to when she's back on her feet."

Ravens father couldn't quite believe wht he was hearing, then somthing registered. "Did you say when she recovers? What do you mean? Is she alright?" Then he visibly regained his composure. "I'm sorry I'm forgetting my manners. Would you like to come in?"

Kane greatfully accepted. When they were seated Kane proceeded to tell Ravens parents about the days events, and of the other things he had heard had happened to her. Her parents listened intently as if they were hearing this only for the first time. When Kane had finished his tale, Ravens father stood up. "Thankyou for bringing this to our attention. We knew she had been getting into fights, but we didn't realise to what extent it was. And to think I was ashamed to be her father. How can I be ashamed of someone who constantly defends herself against people who are bigger than her. Once again thank you."

"Sir, what about my proposal? May she come to work in the castle if she would like?" Asked Kane, as it seemed the man had forgotten.

"Yes of course, how could I refuse?"

Three days later Kane escorted Raven back to her home, and left her to talk to her parents about the offer of work and returned two hours later to find out what she had decide.
1251222112.title: A Job Offer

Raven takes a deep breath as if she is getting ready to make a speech and says, "Yes." and walks toward the palace. You catch up to her and begin to ask her questions, wanting to know more about her.
"Why did you say yes?"
"Because I love to cook, sir, but my mother does all the cooking at home. My father won't let me." It looks as if she wants to say more. As you pass the squires training area Raven looks at it. A small sigh escapes her lips before she catches herself and walks a little quicker.
"You like watching the squires train?" She seems annoyed and confused by all your questions but she answers them nonetheless.
"My friends, yes I have friends, and I like to watch them and make bets on who will finish first, sir."
"Would you like to go through it?" She stops and stares at you, then quickly looks at the ground.
"Commoners can't go through the training course, let alone women, sir," she mutters and jogs toward the kitchens.
"I'm a good friend of the Kings. I'm sure you could, if I asked." You know that she wants to.
"I thank you for your kindness,sir, but women do not act like knights." You reach the kitchens.
"Raven, wait." She stops and looks at you. "What happened to your shoulder?" She gingerly touches her left shoulder.
"When they caught me and started beating me, they used a rock on my shoulder, sir. A very big and heavy rock." With that she quickly goes into the kitchens, not wanting to talk to you anymore.
